Foreign investors such as SoftBank and Tiger Global have bet on the space in recent years.In their letter to the RBI, online travel agency MakeMyTrip, PolicyBazaar and 10 other entities asked authorities to reconsider their decision on Paytm, saying it "could send a negative signal to the global business community" and have "a chilling effect across the fintech sector, discouraging innovation and investment in a critical growth engine of the Indian economy".Advertisement · Scroll to continueThe RBI, which cited "supervisory concerns" and non-compliance with rules as reasons for its decision, did not respond to Reuters request for comment on the letter.Paytm, backed by SoftBank, has said it is confident of continuing operations and sources say it is holding talks with the central bank.holding talks with the central bankMakeMyTrip and PolicyBazaar declined to comment while Paytm did not respond to requests for comment.Paytm's app is one of the most downloaded in India and its flamboyant CEO Vijay Shekhar Sharma is seen as the de facto leader of the startup space, once among India's 100 richest people.Advertisement · Scroll to continueNow, he arguably faces his biggest crisis in trying to save Paytm, which has 100 million monthly users and competes with the likes of Walmart's PhonePe and Google , opens new tab .faces his biggest crisisWalmart's PhonePe and Google , opens new tabPaytm shares fell to a record low of 395 rupees early on Tuesday in Mumbai.Editing by Kirsten DonovanOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing RightsAditya KalraThomson ReutersAditya Kalra is the Company News Editor for Reuters in India, overseeing business coverage and reporting stories on some of the world's biggest companies. He joined Reuters in 2008 and has in recent years written stories on challenges and strategies of a wide array of companies -- from Amazon, Google and Walmart to Xiaomi, Starbucks and Reliance. He also extensively works on deeply-reported and investigative business stories.M. SriramThomson ReutersSriram leads Reuters' deals coverage in India, including reporting and writing on private equity funds, IPOs, venture capital, corporate M&A and regulatory changes. His reportage includes scoops on large transactions as well as deeper analyses and insightful stories on the inner workings of companies, funds and industry trends that fly below the radar. He is a business journalist for five years by training, with a postgraduation from the Asian College of Journalism's Bloomberg program in financial journalism. He graduated from the course's inaugural batch.

title: Analysis: Will shakeup at net-zero targets arbiter be enough to quiet its critics?
author: By Oliver Balch
content: summary4,521 companies have climate targets validated by the Science Based Targets initiative, with 2,837 awaiting validationAmid criticism of its credibility as third-party verifier SBTi moves to charitable status, improves governance and transparencyCriticism remains over its methodology for failing to take account of historical emissions reductionAdvocates are pushing for intensity metric, with carbon emissions tracked on per-unit basisBut, environmental groups say intensity metrics can be a fig-leaf to cover rises in absolute emissionsFebruary 5 - Amid the pervasive scepticism around corporate climate efforts and greenwashing claims, global brands are increasingly turning to what they hope will offer a lifeline of legitimacy: the magical two-word phrase “science-based”.The term is designed to ground net-zero targets in peer-reviewed climate models and confirm that brand commitments credibly align with the Paris Agreement goal of a 1.5 degrees Celsius cap in global temperature rise by 2050.Pivotal is the Science Based Targets initiative , opens new tab (SBTi). Six years after its launch, and with much fanfare, SBTI succeeded in being first to market with a globally recognised corporate net-zero standard , opens new tab back in 2021.Science Based Targets initiative , opens new tabcorporate net-zero standard , opens new tabFrom the start, demand for the standard, which has undergone various tweaks and clarifications, has proved sky-high. At the latest count, 4,521 companies boast comprehensive science-based climate action plans accredited by the initiative. A further 2,837 have “commitments” awaiting validation.Advertisement · Scroll to continueLast week, the initiative announced i , opens new tab t has split from its founding partners (CDP, the UN Global Compact, the World Resources Institute and WWF) and had become a UK charity. This will allow it to benefit from an $18-million donation from the IKEA Foundation.announced i , opens new tabThe grant, which matches a gift of the same amount from the Bezos Earth Fund back in 2021, will help fund a pipeline of ambitious new projects. High on that list is the development of specific standards for six high-impact sectors, including apparel, automotives, and oil and gas. A fuller version of its near-term guidance for financial institutions , opens new tab is also on the cards.near-term guidance for financial institutions , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueMannequins stand behind a shop window with a sale sign. The Science Based Targets initiative is developing specific standards for six high-impact sectors, including apparel. REUTERS/Florence Lo Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabThe organisation also hopes the restructuring will help answer questions about its credibility as a third-party verifier that have been offered by some critics, many of whom also criticise its methodology.Last November, the U.S. chip manufacturer, Intel, widely touted as a leader , opens new tab in environmental management and with a long track record on emissions reduction, announced it would not be submitting its carbon plan to SBTi.widely touted as a leader , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueIn its Climate Transition Action Plan report , opens new tab , the chipmaker criticised the methodology for its “absolute contraction approach”, which it says fails to allow companies to account for historical emission reduction, a move that puts early leaders at a “disadvantage” compared with companies only now getting started.Climate Transition Action Plan report , opens new tabIt is an argument that finds favour with Phillip Cornell, principal for sustainability and energy at Economist Impact, a research and creative agency. As he states: “A focus on near-term reductions could penalise companies which have been reducing emissions significantly to date.”Advertisement · Scroll to continueSecond, Intel finds fault with the methodology’s refusal to consider the positive emission benefits that a brand’s products might deliver for other users. Without taking into account this “hand print”, any large-scale increase in chip production, something that Intel maintains helps in “driving climate change solutions”, will fall foul of SBTi’s absolute emissions’ rule.Chris Hocknell, director of the London-based sustainability consultancy Eight Versa, echoes the criticism. While he concedes that some of the emissions incurred from rapid business expansion can be mitigated, many high-growth companies – especially small firms and those in emerging markets – will struggle to keep their absolute emissions from rising.Model Y cars are pictured at the Tesla Gigafactory for electric cars in Gruenheide, Germany. Critics says SBTi's methodology does not take into account the positive emission benefits that a brand’s products might deliver. Patrick Pleul/Pool via REUTERS Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabHe gives the example , opens new tab of the U.S. electric vehicle brand, Tesla. In 2022, the decision by car owners to switch to the company’s low-emission models helped abate 2.3 million metric tons of CO2 (sometimes referred to as the “Scope 4” effect), he states. The more cars that leave Tesla’s assembly plants, however, the higher its absolute emissions creep up.gives the example , opens new tabHence, Hocknell’s criticism of the absolute contraction measure as a “luxury metric” that favours large, low-growth companies in developed markets with vast resources to invest in mitigation.Hocknell is consequently one of a growing number of advocates pushing for SBTi to replace its absolute metric with an intensity metric , opens new tab , which sees carbon emissions tracked on a per-unit basis rather than as an overall total.intensity metric , opens new tabSBTI’s methodology , opens new tab currently allows for intensity metrics (see Criteria 4.5.3), but only for large companies (over 250 employees) and only for Scope 3 (indirect) emissions. To be eligible, the physical intensity of a product’s emissions needs to reduce at 7% per year (revised up from a previous threshold of 2%) for near-term targets, and by 97% overall for long-term targets.SBTI’s methodology , opens new tab“That level of intensity reduction (97%) ends up similar to the absolute reduction because it’s been set so aggressively,” Hocknell says.Intensity metrics are not without their own problems, however. Environmental campaign groups point to their widespread use among oil and gas companies and banks, for example. Not only is the metric used as a fig-leaf to cover ongoing rises in absolute emissions, critics maintain , opens new tab , but the formulas often vary greatly and can also include carbon offsets.critics maintain , opens new tabEnvironmental campaigners are critical of the widespread use among oil and gas companies of intensity metrics, which are allowed for in SBTi's methodology. REUTERS/Andy Buchanan Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabLaying arguments over the specifics of metric calculation aside, many fear that a shift away from absolute metrics could encourage brands to take their eye off the end game: namely, keeping the global temperature from not increasing more than 1.5C by 2050.Rory Sullivan, co-founder and chief executive of the UK advisory firm Chronos Sustainability, says: “If you are concerned about climate change, it is hard to see why you would argue against it (absolute contraction) because net-zero requires absolute emission reductions.”Dexter Galvin, chief commercial and partnerships officer at one of SBTi’s core partner groups, CDP, takes a similar position. That said, he is quick to stress an openness on the part of SBTi to take on board feedback from companies and modify its methodology where appropriate.He notes, for example, changes in the past , opens new tab to accommodate issues that companies in Latin America and Asia face due to the relatively high average emissions intensity of the local electricity grids on which they depend.changes in the past , opens new tabWhile he admits this problem “wasn’t terribly well represented” initially, he maintains that SBTi’s steps to resolve the issue have since resulted in much greater uptake in both regions. That said, “the interpretation of it being a western methodology is still there,” he concedes.SBTi itself points to a number of recent improvements to its technical governance, , opens new tab including the creation of an independent body to make decisions on the development of its standard and the revision process.technical governance, , opens new tabA pylon is pictured near a power plant outside Tianjin, China. In the past, SBTi has made changes to accommodate issues that companies in Asia face due to the higher average emissions intensity of local electricity grids. REUTERS/Thomas Peter Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabThe body might go some way to addressing criticisms against SBTi’s role as both standard setter and verifier, a service for which it charges a fee. This apparent conflict of interest is highlighted in a letter sent last September to the U.S. House of Representatives’ Committee on Science, Space and Technology by Bill Baue, senior director of the not-for-profit platform r3.0 and a long-time critic of SBTi.“[SBTI is] a SBT (science-based target) standard setter that also serves as a SBT validator with a business model tied to validation growth, whose private interest thus diverges from the public interest, as it seeks to ‘keep the customer satisfied,’” Baue’s submission states.SBTi’s move anticipates a major review of SBTi’s corporate net-zero standard during the course of 2024, the first of its kind since its launch three years ago.In an attempt to underline its openness to feedback, SBTi has also recently appointed a compliance director, whose mandate, among other tasks, includes establishing a robust system for processing “complaints, allegations and appeals” by participating companies.Beyond the grumbling of individual brands, however, there’s a wider complaint around the general transparency of SBTi’s calculations and decision-making process.A comment piece , opens new tab published in the journal Nature Climate Change last year accused the organisation and its participating companies of “rarely” disclosing the inputs used to determine brands’ individual climate targets.comment piece , opens new tab“This makes it almost impossible to reproduce SBTs and verify or refute SBTi’s claim of a scientific basis,” the article states.It is a charge that SBTi vehemently refutes. “Unlike most other voluntary climate initiatives that define best practice without a mechanism to assess conformance, the SBTi’s target validation provides comprehensive assessment of submitted targets,” a spokesman told The Ethical Corporation.Validated companies are also obliged under SBTi’s official criteria , opens new tab to publicly disclose their greenhouse gas inventories and target progress on an annual basis, the spokesperson added. Stakeholders can “easily cross reference” with the information published on SBTi’s target dashboard , opens new tab .official criteria , opens new tabSBTi’s target dashboard , opens new tabHowever, brands can also have their commitments marked as removed from the dashboard if they are judged to have fallen short, a sanction meted out to 186 companies since the initiative’s inception, including high-profile firms such as Amazon, Eurostar, Kohl’s, Vale, and Yahoo Japan.U.S. e-retailer Amazon blamed its removal in August last year on changes in SBTi’s submission requirements. Going forwards, it said it would seek to set science-based targets “with other organisations and credible third-party validators”.Nevertheless, Galvin at CDP does not anticipate SBTi weakening its removal policy any time soon. If anything, with emissions “creeping up”, it should get stricter, he argues.It is ludicrous to suggest business is meeting its full obligations in the fight against climate change, he insists: “They (SBTi) need to stick to their guns on these things … the job of the Science Based Targets initiative is to constantly raise the bar.”It is one of the few points on which both SBTi and its critics can concur.Opinions expressed are those of the author. They do not reflect the views of Reuters News, which, under the Trust Principles, is committed to integrity, independence, and freedom from bias. Ethical Corporation Magazine, a part of Reuters Professional, is owned by Thomson Reuters and operates independently of Reuters News.Purchase Licensing RightsOliver BalchOliver Balch is an independent journalist and writer, specialising on business’s role in society. He has been a regular contributor to The Ethical Corporation since 2004. He also writes for a range of UK and international media. Oliver holds a PhD in Anthropology / Latin American Studies from Cambridge University.

title: Energy heavyweights push European shares higher; Germany's DAX hits fresh record high
author: By Sruthi Shankar and Shashwat Chauhan
content: summaryCompaniesBP rallies after upbeat earnings, buyback increaseUBS slips after Q4 resultsNordic Semiconductor sinks after bleak outlookSTOXX 600 up 0.7%Feb 6 (Reuters) - European stocks advanced on Tuesday as bumper earnings from BP and higher crude prices propelled energy giants higher, while investors took comfort from fresh stimulus for China's battered financial markets.The pan-European STOXX 600 index (.STOXX) , opens new tab closed 0.7% higher, with the energy index (.SXEP) , opens new tab leading the charge, up 2.1%, tracking an advance in crude oil prices.(.STOXX) , opens new tab(.SXEP) , opens new tabLondon-listed oil giant BP (BP.L) , opens new tab climbed 5.5% after reporting better-than-expected fourth quarter earnings and accelerating the pace of its share repurchases.BP(BP.L) , opens new tab"There are also elements of strong comparatives, particularly in the fourth quarter numbers, when the oil price significantly spiked following Russia's invasion of Ukraine," Richard Hunter, head of markets at Interactive Investor said."Even so, BP is well prepared as a business to withstand the cyclical trials which follows a wavering price."China-exposed miners (.SXPP) , opens new tab also added 1.4% amid renewed talks of official support from Chinese authorities, while industrials (.SXNP) , opens new tab also gained 1.4%.(.SXPP) , opens new tabrenewed talks(.SXNP) , opens new tabGermany's DAX index (.GDAXI) , opens new tab notched a fresh record high, ending 0.8% higher, lifted by a 3.2% jump in Siemens Energy (ENR1n.DE) , opens new tab .(.GDAXI) , opens new tab(ENR1n.DE) , opens new tabActing as a catalyst to gains, yields on government bonds across the continent took a breather, with the yield on the benchmark 10-year German note last at 2.291%.Advertisement · Scroll to continueStill, there was an element of caution after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell pushed back firmly against speculation of imminent rate cuts, prompting investors to reassess the trajectory of rates this year.pushed backEuropean stocks reached a two-year high last week, helped by earnings and gains in technology stocks on optimism about artificial intelligence (AI), but strong U.S. data and cautious comments from central bank policymakers have stalled the rally.Advertisement · Scroll to continueOf the 85 STOXX 600 companies that have reported earnings for the fourth quarter so far, 55.3% have beaten analyst estimates, LSEG data showed.On the downside, Swiss lender UBS (UBSG.S) , opens new tab it would restart share buybacks and find $3 billion more in cost savings from integrating Credit Suisse. Its shares, however, dropped 4.4% with analysts pointing to slightly lower-than-expected profitability targets.UBS(UBSG.S) , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueItalian pump manufacturer Interpump (ITPG.MI) , opens new tab lost 6.9% after brokerage Equita trimmed its estimates and price target on the stock.(ITPG.MI) , opens new tabNorwegian fabless chipmaker Nordic Semiconductor (NOD.OL) , opens new tab slumped 22.3% after it warned of low revenue into 2024 due to Internet of Things (IoT) sector headwinds.(NOD.OL) , opens new tabMeanwhile, investors also appeared to shrug off a reading that showed German industrial orders unexpectedly jumped in December, driven by "an exceptionally" high number of aircraft orders.showedAdvertisement · Scroll to continueA separate European Central Bank poll showed consumers have trimmed their expectations for inflation over the next 12 months, in a sign the ECB's credit-tightening efforts are having an impact.European Central Bank pollReporting by Sruthi Shankar and Shashwat Chauhan in Bengaluru; Editing by Dhanya Ann Thoppil, Varun H K and Ros RussellOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: EU ‘Italian Job’ starts with winning over citizens
author: By Peter Thal Larsen
content: LONDON, Feb 6 (Reuters Breakingviews) - Call it the Italian Job. Two former prime ministers of Italy are on separate missions with the same goal: to revive the European Union’s competitiveness. Mario Draghi and Enrico Letta are crisscrossing the continent meeting with business leaders, bureaucrats, and bankers. Yet to have any chance of succeeding, they will need to persuade European citizens a revamped bloc can work for their benefit.business leadersFor all the handwringing about Europe’s lack of competitive edge, the shortfall is hard to discern in economic data. Per-capita GDP in the EU is about 30% lower than in the United States, when measured on a purchasing power parity basis. Yet that’s partly because Europeans work fewer hours than Americans – and the gap is broadly stable. Nor is the EU obviously a trade laggard. For the past decade it has consistently maintained a collective current account surplus of more than 2% of GDP with the rest of the world, except in 2022, after Russia invaded Ukraine. Europeans also live longer.Reuters GraphicsNevertheless, Europe faces daunting external challenges. When the EU launched its single market in 1993, lowering barriers to trade, movement of labour, and capital flows across the continent, it was following the prevailing free-market orthodoxy. Three decades on, the world looks vastly different. The United States has deployed tariffs and sanctions to restrict cross-border trade. Tensions with China, the Covid-19 pandemic, and the fallout from the war in Ukraine have prompted governments and companies to reconsider global supply chains. This shift affects an open economy like the EU more than others.Advertisement · Scroll to continueEnergy is a particular weak spot. Russia’s attack on Ukraine exposed Europe’s dependence on imported gas. Though the bloc has quickly shifted to other suppliers of hydrocarbons, the upheaval has pushed up the price of power, prompting industrial groups to shift production elsewhere. While the crisis has spurred investment in renewable power, this transition will take decades.European business leaders also fret about the continent’s dependence on overseas technology. Most advanced semiconductors come from Asia, particularly Taiwan. Despite the European Commission’s efforts to regulate and rein in tech giants, the likes of Microsoft (MSFT.O) , opens new tab , Alphabet (GOOGL.O) , opens new tab and Amazon.com (AMZN.O) , opens new tab dominate. “When I move data to the cloud I have a choice of three American suppliers,” says a European bank CEO. The vast computing resources required for artificial intelligence look set to embed large U.S. tech groups even more deeply into European business.(MSFT.O) , opens new tab(GOOGL.O) , opens new tab(AMZN.O) , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueMeanwhile, the EU is ill-equipped to match the muscular industrial policies adopted by the United States. President Joe Biden has unleashed generous subsidies to stimulate American manufacturing, boost local production of semiconductors, and attract green technology. The EU lacks the coordinated fiscal firepower to respond. European companies are gratefully pocketing U.S. subsidies. Investment dollars are flowing elsewhere. Capital spending by European companies fell slightly between 2015 and 2022 after taking account of inflation, the McKinsey Global Institute calculates , opens new tab . Over the same period, their U.S. counterparts upped investment by 30%.calculates , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueThe subsidy race has exposed flaws in Europe’s single market. Its architects, led by the late Jacques Delors, wanted to create a level playing field across the continent. Strict rules prevented rich governments from favouring local firms. The EU suspended that regime during the pandemic and has struggled to reintroduce it as states supported power suppliers stricken by spiking gas prices and handed out subsidies to green energy producers. Between March 2022 and August 2023, the Commission approved state support schemes worth 733 billion euros , opens new tab , according to the Financial Times. That rivals the sums being spent across the Atlantic – but pits European governments against each other.worth 733 billion euros , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueWhen it comes to addressing the EU’s problems, proposals fall into two broad categories. The first is to deregulate. Business leaders point to the lengthy approval processes required to clean up industrial facilities or get new drugs onto the market. “We have the oldest industries in the world and the most regulations,” sighs one European boss. Competition rules are a particular bugbear. The Commission has spent 18 months examining the merger of French telecoms group Orange’s (ORAN.PA) , opens new tab Spanish operations with rival MásMóvil, which would reduce the number of mobile operators in the country from four to three. Frustrated executives point out that China, whose population is 30 times the size of Spain’s, has just three major operators.(ORAN.PA) , opens new tabrival MásMóvilYet even as they complain about red tape in Brussels, companies are also pushing for more centralised decision-making, particularly on finance. The single market has failed to lower national barriers in banking, limiting the scope for cross-border competition. The EU’s attempts to unlock financial flows through a capital markets union have been a flop, in part because governments and national regulators are reluctant to give up power.It is up to the former Italian premiers to resolve these contradictions. Letta is due to deliver his conclusions in the next few months; Draghi’s recommendations will follow later in the year. Yet perhaps their biggest challenge is finding a way to enthuse EU voters. In the 1990s, leaders sold the single market as improving choice and opportunity for ordinary Europeans. These days the audience is more sceptical. Citizens fret about immigration. Small and medium-sized businesses are concerned about larger rivals. Consolidation could raise prices for consumers. European farmers are protesting about green regulations.are protestingPoliticians have tapped into the anti-Brussels mood: Geert Wilders, whose far-right Freedom Party won last year’s Dutch election, ran on a manifesto that included a promise to hold a referendum on EU membership. The Alternative for Germany and Marine Le Pen’s National Rally in France, which according to polls will pick up seats in June’s election for the European Parliament, have a eurosceptic streak.Europeans may yet accept the benefits of reform, as a way of ensuring greater collective security in a less friendly world. A revamped EU-wide industrial policy could help to create or preserve jobs in left-behind regions. A faster shift to green energy would improve air quality as well as reducing dependence on imported gas. To have any chance of success, though, the Italian Job of boosting competitiveness will have to start with EU citizens.Follow @peter_tl , opens new tab on X@peter_tl , opens new tab(The author is a Reuters Breakingviews columnist. The opinions expressed are his own.)Editing by Francesco Guerrera and Streisand NetoOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabOpinions expressed are those of the author. They do not reflect the views of Reuters News, which, under the Trust Principles, is committed to integrity, independence, and freedom from bias.Purchase Licensing Rights

title: India needs less Tesla, more Toyota
author: By Pranav Kiran
content: BENGALURU, Feb 6 (Reuters Breakingviews) - India is determined to lure Elon Musk's Tesla (TSLA.O) , opens new tab to set up a local factory to make electric vehicles. Yet slower global demand for pure electric vehicles strengthens the case for the world's third largest auto market to embrace hybrids like those made by Japan's Toyota Motor (7203.T) , opens new tab .(TSLA.O) , opens new tab(7203.T) , opens new tabCars running on a mix of battery and gas are currently treated as luxury items and taxed domestically at over 43%, while locally-made EVs only face a 5% charge. India's trade department has privately supported calls from Japanese automakers to lower taxes on hybrids. That looks smart, especially now that Tesla's shares have fallen 24% this year and Chinese carmakers are slashing prices to entice buyers.supportedIndia needs to accelerate with caution. The fundamental drivers of weak demand - range anxiety and affordability - are far bigger issues in India’s nascent market. Last year, only 2% of cars sold in the country were electric. Carmakers like Tata Motors (TAMO.NS) , opens new tab and Mahindra (MAHM.NS) , opens new tab are scaling up but customers have only a few options to choose from. And for now, there is only one commercial charging point for every 200 electric vehicles, compared to one in 10 for China, per Bain & Company , opens new tab .(TAMO.NS) , opens new tab(MAHM.NS) , opens new tabBain & Company , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueReuters GraphicsUltimately India is unlikely give up its preference for EVs. It wants to curb emissions but it also wants to cut its crude oil import bill that contributes to its current account deficit. A high deficit can lead to weakness in the rupee and impacts the country's perceived economic stability.However, EVs are only as clean as the energy grid that powers them. So while Tata Motors' Chief Financial Officer P.B. Balaji is calling for the government to choose which clean car technology it is going to back and opposes lowering taxes on hybrids, the reality is that India's coal-heavy electricity grid complicates the decision.Advertisement · Scroll to continueIt might take between seven and ten years before electric vehicles have an emissions footprint as low as hybrids that are strong enough to run on battery power alone, HSBC analysts estimate. That makes hybrids an attractive option for India.The shifting global consensus will also vindicate companies earlier seen as EV laggards. The $38 billion Maruti Suzuki (MRTI.NS) , opens new tab , the largest passenger car manufacturer in India, expects , opens new tab hybrids will make up 25% of its portfolio by the financial year 2031, compared to 15% for pure EVs. Tesla may soon be coming to India but hybrids look set to claim a bigger spot on the road too.(MRTI.NS) , opens new tabexpects , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueFollow @PranavKiranBV , opens new tab on X@PranavKiranBV , opens new tab(The author is a Reuters Breakingviews columnist. The opinions expressed are his own)CONTEXT NEWSIndia needs to make clear which clean-car technology it intends to support to meet its zero-emission goals, Tata Motors' Chief Financial Officer P.B. Balaji said on Feb. 2.Tata Motors is urging the government not to cut taxes on hybrid cars as they are more polluting than pure electric models, Reuters reported on Jan. 17, citing three sources and a company letter.Advertisement · Scroll to continueIndia's trade department has backed lowering domestic taxes on hybrid vehicles to help the transition to cleaner energy sources, following demands by Japanese car makers, Reuters reported on Jan. 10 citing government and industry sources.Editing by Una Galani and Nivedita BhattacharjeeOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabOpinions expressed are those of the author. They do not reflect the views of Reuters News, which, under the Trust Principles, is committed to integrity, independence, and freedom from bias.Purchase Licensing Rights

title: Toyota holds off response on wage talks after first round
author: By Tetsushi Kajimoto and Maki Shiraki
content: summaryCompaniesToyota Motor has long served as bellwether of wage talksHonda Motor strikes deal with its union in first roundBlue-chips seen to offer 2024 pay hikes on March 13BOJ count on wage hikes to pave way for policy normalisationTOKYO, Feb 21 (Reuters) - Toyota Motor (7203.T) , opens new tab , the world's biggest automaker, did not reach an immediate agreement with its union over demands for hefty pay hikes on Wednesday but will continue talks in coming days, raising doubts about current expectations for wage talks.(7203.T) , opens new tabToyota has long served as the pace-setter for Japan's annual spring labour-management wage offensive, and had accepted the union's demand in full on the first day of the annual wage negotiations in the past two years."I understand that we both have mutual recognition about the need to secure talent by improving wages and other treatment," said Hiroki Akiyama, deputy secretary-general of the Federation of All Toyota Workers' Union."However, we have not yet reached a stage today where we can discuss pay levels. Negotiations have just started so we will deepen concrete debates while helping each union member cope with the situations they are in."Advertisement · Scroll to continueIn a sign last year's wage growth last year still had momentum, Honda Motor (7267.T) , opens new tab , Japan's second-largest automaker, on Wednesday said it responded in full to union demands for a record rise in base pay and bonus payments.(7267.T) , opens new tabPrime Minister Fumio Kishida's government is counting on wage talks to drive sustainable pay hikes and stable inflation and put a decisive end to about two decades of deflation.Advertisement · Scroll to continueThis year's labour talks are being closely watched by the Bank of Japan, which sees sustainable wage and price hikes as a prerequisite to normalise monetary policy.Toyota's labour-management talks are scheduled to take place again on Feb. 28 andMarch 6, before a formal offer for 2024 pay hikes on March 13 along with other blue-chip Japanese companies. If Toyota agrees to the union's demands, it would mark the fourth straight year of full acceptance.Advertisement · Scroll to continueThe Federation of All Toyota Workers' Union demands record bonus payments worth 7.6 months of salary, while seeking monthly pay raises of up to 28,440 yen ($189.57) depending on job qualifications and occupation.Japanese labour unions have entered this year's annual wage talks with demands for pay rises well in excess of last year's hikes, which were the biggest in more than three decades.Many blue-chip companies are due to formally offer unions handsome pay increases on March 13, followed by small firms in the coming months.Advertisement · Scroll to continuePrivate-sector economists expect major firms to offer wage hikes of about 3.9% on average, the largest in 31 years. Excluding seniority-led pay scale, however, base pay that determines the strength of incomes, may undershoot rising prices, heaping downward pressure on real wages.If workers manage to secure the expected wage hikes, that could lay the ground for the central bank to exit its negative rates as early as in March or April.($1 = 150.0200 yen)Reporting by Tetsushi Kajimoto and Maki Shiraki; Editing by Chang-Ran Kim, Sam Holmes and David EvansOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: Wall Street equities fall with interest rates, earnings in focus
author: By Sinéad Carew and Johann M Cherian
content: summaryCompaniesUS service sector growth picks up in Jan - ISMCaterpillar scales record high after upbeat resultsEstee Lauder jumps on job-cut planCatalent up on Novo Nordisk parent's $11.5-bln buyout dealIndexes down: Dow 0.71%, S&P 0.32%, Nasdaq 0.20%Feb 5 (Reuters) - Wall Street's main indexes closed lower on Monday after Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell pushed back firmly against speculation that rate cuts would be imminent, while investors assessed a mixed bag of U.S. earnings reports.In an interview aired on Sunday, Powell said more evidence on a sustainable downtrend in inflation was needed to warrant lower rates, while Minneapolis Fed President Neel Kashkari wrote in an essay published on Monday that a resilient economy could defer rate cuts for some time.an interviewNeel KashkariAdvertisement · Scroll to continueFresh data from the Institute for Supply Management showed the U.S. services sector's growth picked up in January, with a measure of input prices rising to an 11-month high.U.S. services sector's growthThis added to doubts about rate cuts, already kindled by Friday's data, which signaled the labor market's resilience in the face of tight credit conditions.dataNonfarm payrollsAdding pressure was U.S. Treasuries, with 10-year yields up for second day straight and hitting their highest level since late January."Chairman Powell threw a wet blanket over trading today, taking any chance of a March rate cut off the table," said Jack Ablin, chief investment officer at Cresset Capital in Chicago.Advertisement · Scroll to continueBut with all three of Wall Street's major indexes paring losses as the session wore on, Ablin said investors are likely conflicted since positive economic data supports higher rates."Equity investors are torn between the higher rates and the stronger growth. They're no longer sure that good is bad news," he said. "Stronger growth on the economic front gives the Fed more flexibility to keep rates higher and know they're not going to kill the economy but still have a potent weapon against inflation."Advertisement · Scroll to continueAnd since Monday's decline followed record high closing levels in the benchmark S&P 500 (.SPX) , opens new tab and the blue-chip Dow (.DJI) , opens new tab on Friday, Carol Schleif, chief investment officer at BMO family office in Minneapolis, Minnesota, saw it as a potential opportunity for investors who had been on the sidelines.(.SPX) , opens new tab(.DJI) , opens new tab"The market had gotten way out over its skis, especially coming out of November, December," Schleif said, adding that she was "not viewing this as the start of a major pullback."Advertisement · Scroll to continueThe Dow Jones Industrial Average (.DJI) , opens new tab fell 274.30 points, or 0.71% , to 38,380.12, the S&P 500 (.SPX) , opens new tab lost 15.80 points, or 0.32%, to 4,942.81 and the Nasdaq Composite (.IXIC) , opens new tab lost 31.28 points, or 0.20%, to 15,597.68.(.DJI) , opens new tab(.SPX) , opens new tab(.IXIC) , opens new tabTraders work on the floor at the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York City, U.S., January 29, 2024. REUTERS/Brendan McDermid/File Photo Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabThe S&P 500 materials sector (.SPLRCM) , opens new tab was the biggest sector decliner, ending down 2.5%, dragged down by a 15.6% decline in Air Products (APD.N) , opens new tab after the industrial gas manufacturer forecast 2024 profit below estimates.(.SPLRCM) , opens new tab(APD.N) , opens new tabOf 11 major S&P sectors, only two gained ground with technology (.SPLRCT) , opens new tab adding 0.6% and a 0.3% gain in healthcare (.SPXHC) , opens new tab .(.SPLRCT) , opens new tab(.SPXHC) , opens new tabResults were in from nearly half of the S&P 500 firms and fourth-quarter earnings estimates were improving sharply, with about 80% of the reports beating expectations, according to LSEG data on Friday.improving sharply"Mostly earnings season has been pretty mixed bag. It's been more stock specific than industry specific," said BMO's Schleif.Caterpillar (CAT.N) , opens new tab closed up 2% after hitting a record high following its report of a higher quarterly profit, while Estee Lauder (EL.N) , opens new tab shares surged 12% as the MAC lipstick maker aims to cut about 3% to 5% of its workforce.(CAT.N) , opens new tabhigher quarterly profit(EL.N) , opens new tabaims to cutBoeing (BA.N) , opens new tab shares slipped 1.3% after it said a new quality glitch in some 737 MAX planes would delay some deliveries.(BA.N) , opens new tabTesla (TSLA.O) , opens new tab shares closed down 3.7% after touching its lowest level since May during the session. Piper Sandler slashed the stock's price target.(TSLA.O) , opens new tabNvidia (NVDA.O) , opens new tab hit a fresh record high following a price-target raise by Goldman Sachs and closed up 4.8%.(NVDA.O) , opens new tabprice-target raiseCatalent (CTLT.N) , opens new tab shares soared 9.7% on Novo Nordisk parent (NOVOb.CO) , opens new tab Novo Holdings' plans to buy the contract drugmaker in an $11.5-billion all-cash deal.(CTLT.N) , opens new tab(NOVOb.CO) , opens new tabplans to buyDeclining issues outnumbered advancers by a 4.2-to-1 ratio on the NYSE. There were 142 new highs and 124 new lows on the NYSE.On the Nasdaq 1,167 stocks rose and 3,136 fell as declining issues outnumbered advancers by about a 2.7-to-1 ratio.The S&P 500 posted 29 new 52-week highs and 11 new lows while the Nasdaq recorded 86 new highs and 209 new lows.On US exchanges 10.99 billion shares changed hands compared with the 11.58 billion moving average for the last 20 sessions.Reporting by Johann M Cherian and Ankika Biswas in Bengaluru; Editing by Pooja Desai, Maju Samuel and Aurora EllisOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: IT, oil and gas stocks lead rise in Indian shares
author: By Bharath Rajeswaran
content: BENGALURU, Feb 6 (Reuters) - Indian shares advanced on Tuesday, led by information technology stocks on prospects of a soft landing in the U.S. economy improving and supported by a sustained rally in oil marketing companies.The NSE Nifty 50 index (.NSEI) , opens new tab added 0.72% at 21,929.40, while the S&P BSE Sensex (.BSESN) , opens new tab edged up 0.63% to 72,186.09.(.NSEI) , opens new tab(.BSESN) , opens new tab"The buoyancy in domestic equities is set to continue, supported by strong liquidity, both from retail and foreign investors," said Avinash Gorakshakar, head of research at Profitmart Securities.The IT index (.NIFTYIT) , opens new tab rose 2.92% after strong data from the U.S. services sector provided further evidence of strength in the world's largest economy, a key geography for India's software companies.(.NIFTYIT) , opens new tabstrong data from the U.S. services sectorMeanwhile, data showed foreign portfolio investors added IT stocks worth 44.85 billion rupees ($540.01 million) on a net basis in January despite selling in other major sectors, indicating steady inflows into IT.dataTata Consultancy Services (TCS.NS) , opens new tab and HCLTech (HCLT.NS) , opens new tab gained about 4% each and were among the top five Nifty 50 gainers.(TCS.NS) , opens new tab(HCLT.NS) , opens new tabThe oil and gas index (.NIFOILGAS) , opens new tab surged 2.67%, extending its rally to the third session. Bharat Petroleum Corporation (BPCL.NS) , opens new tab , Hindustan Petroleum Corp (HPCL.NS) , opens new tab and Indian Oil Corporation (IOC.NS) , opens new tab gained between 5.3% and 6.2%.(.NIFOILGAS) , opens new tab(BPCL.NS) , opens new tab(HPCL.NS) , opens new tab(IOC.NS) , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueSince their quarterly results in the final two weeks of January, BPCL, HPCL and IOC have climbed between 17% and 35%.In-line quarterly results and the government's focus on fiscal prudence are likely to support sentiment in Indian markets, although bouts of profit-booking cannot be ruled out due to elevated valuations, Gorakshakar added.focus on fiscal prudencePaytm (PAYT.NS) , opens new tab rose about 3%, rebounding off a record low. It slumped about 42% in the previous three sessions after a regulatory crackdown on its payments bank.(PAYT.NS) , opens new tabreboundingAdvertisement · Scroll to continueHealth insurance stocks jumped after a government panel recommended a reduction in goods and services tax rate on health and term insurance products. HDFC Life Insurance (HDFL.NS) , opens new tab added 5.22% and was the second highest percentage gainer on Nifty 50.(HDFL.NS) , opens new tab($1 = 83.0535 Indian rupees)Reporting by Bharath Rajeswaran in Bengaluru; Editing by Savio D'Souza and Janane VenkatramanOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: Analysis: Why the next two years will make or break battle to rescue tropical forests
author: By Terry Slavin
content: summaryDeforestation in the Cerrado, Brazil’s agricultural heartland, increased by 43% in 2022 despite falling in AmazonPresident Lula da Silva in drive to build nature-friendly economy ahead of COP30 in Belem, but faces hostile CongressCommitment by major soya producers at COP28 to halt deforestation described as ‘too little, too late’ by activists for excluding beefBi-partisan group of U.S. senators latest to protest JBS application to list on NYSEGlobal Canopy chief optimistic moves to ban imports linked to deforestation and new tools for investors will turn tideFebruary 5 - To see how escalating deforestation and rising temperatures are already having profound impacts, look no further than the Amazon rainforest, where water levels last year reached their lowest since measurement began, threatening both humans and animals, and the integrity of the world’s biggest tropical forest.In the lead up to COP28, the annual Forest Declaration Assessment report , opens new tab found that despite more than 140 countries pledging at COP26 to end deforestation by 2030, tree loss increased by 4% in 2022 compared with 2021. The amount would have been higher had not Brazil, under its new president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, and two other important rainforest countries, Indonesia and Malaysia, achieved drastic reductions.Forest Declaration Assessment report , opens new tabSo, while activists such as Global Canopy celebrated the fact that the promise to halt and reverse deforestation by 2030 made it into the final text at COP28 for the first time, they also called attention to the fact that global pledges to end deforestation, stretching back to the 2014 New York Declaration (when the deadline was 2020), have rung hollow.Last month, there was a grim reminder of how easily progress can be reversed, when official data from Brazil showed that deforestation in the Cerrado biome, Brazil’s agricultural heartland, increased by 43% on the previous year, even as deforestation in the Amazon fell 50%.Advertisement · Scroll to continueMark Titley, a researcher at supply chain mapping initiative Trase, said the Cerrado is the frontline of Brazil’s deforestation. “In 2020, around half of the soy produced on recently cleared land in Brazil was from the Cerrado.” He said this was more than three times the amount of deforestation in the Amazon, and had generated an equivalent amount of CO2 emissions.And while eight of the top commodity traders convened by the Tropical Forest Alliance collectively pledged , opens new tab at COP28 to implement commitments to halt deforestation linked to soy in all biomes in Brazil by 2030, including in the Cerrado, Titley said the commitment was too little, and too late.collectively pledged , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueA boy walks on a dry area of the Igarape do Taruma stream which flows into the Rio Negro river, as the water level at a major river port in Brazil's Amazon rainforest hit its lowest point in at least 121 years on Monday, in Manaus, Brazil, October 16, 2023. REUTERS/Bruno Kelly Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tab“When it comes to zero-deforestation commitments, the major beef traders have focused on direct sourcing from the Amazon, leaving the Cerrado largely unprotected,” he said. “A few soy traders are making commitments that extend to the Cerrado, but the sector’s collective statement at COP28 set a target date of 2030, (which is) much too far away. With a date so far in the future, allowing many more years of clearance, there could be much less left to protect."Advertisement · Scroll to continueHowever, Jose Pugas, partner and head of responsible investment for Brazilian asset manager JGP, takes a more optimistic stance. He said in an interview at COP28 that he was encouraged by progress by leading agricultural companies on deforestation-free soy, with one of the traders, Cargill, vowing in November to extend its commitment to cotton, wheat and corn in Brazil, Argentina and Uruguay.Pugas said there’s also been progress on deforestation related to the beef industry, which is alone responsible for 37% of the country’s emissions , opens new tab . Although not reported by international media, he said, one of Brazil’s big three beef exporters, Marfrig, announced at COP28 that it would bring forward plans to control 100% of its direct and indirect livestock supply chain, in all Brazil’s biomes, from the initial target of 2030 to 2025.37% of the country’s emissions , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continue“I’m optimistic that more and more, companies and farmers that are still dependent on deforestation for soy production, for beef production, for any kind of production, will find there is no market for them,” Pugas said.The availability of technology to trace the origins of commodities in their supply chains means companies can be held accountable, he said, and added that it is increasingly difficult for them to claim that they are complying with national legislation that permits them to legally deforest. “There is very clear pressure that zero-deforestation is zero-deforestation, not zero illegal deforestation,” he said.Still, Minerva, another of the big three, has made no deforestation commitment. And there has been a storm of controversy over the application by JBS, the world’s biggest producer of animal protein, to list its shares on the New York Stock Exchange. Last month a bipartisan group of U.S. senators joined environmental groups in urge the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission to closely scrutinise JBS’s criminal and environmental track record, including illegal deforestation, , opens new tab which the company claims in its SEC filing to have fixed.including illegal deforestation, , opens new tabWorkers harvest soybeans on a farm in the central Brazilian state of Mato Grosso. REUTERS/Paulo Whitaker Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabJBS, however, is listed on the Brazil stock market, and in a recent column , opens new tab for The Ethical Corporation, Pugas argued that his company’s approach was to “actively engage” with all three of the big beef producers to try to promote positive changes. It is co-leading the Climate Action 100+ engagement with JBS, and working with it on manure mismanagement as part of the FAIRR initiative.in a recent column , opens new tabHe added that more than 150 countries at COP28 had called for agriculture to be included in country’s action plans, known as nationally determined contributions, so there will be greater pressure on investors to play their part in helping companies to decrease deforestation risk.For the moment, Pugas is among a distinct minority. Global Canopy’s latest Deforestation Action Tracker , opens new tab found that just 10% of institutional investors with climate commitments have a deforestation policy in place for these high-risk commodities.Deforestation Action Tracker , opens new tabYet Niki Mardas, executive director of Global Canopy, said in an interview he believes investors will no longer be able to close their eyes to the issue, most crucially due to regulators in key markets cracking down on imports of goods linked to deforestation.This is a reference to the EU’s Deforestation Regulation, which will apply to companies trading in cattle, cocoa, coffee, oil palm, rubber, soya and wood from 2025, and similar legislation proposed in the UK and the U.S.“I think it becomes an unavoidable issue. And while those regulations don't currently apply to the finance sector, they have deep implications for the companies that are invested in by these financial institutions and create risks that aren't fully understood that well, either by the companies themselves, but even less well by those that invest in them,” said Mardas.An agent of the Brazilian Institute for the Environment and Renewable Natural Resources (IBAMA) inspects a tree extracted from the Amazon rainforest, in a sawmill during an operation to combat deforestation, in Placas, Para State, Brazil. REUTERS/Ueslei Marcelino Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPressure is also coming from other directions, including the Task Force for Nature-related Financial Disclosure, “which we can expect to become mandatory over time, following the pathway of the Taskforce for Climate Related Financial Disclosure, and because we now have a global biodiversity framework at the international level.”Mardas admits that such optimism is tempered by the fact that nature-positive finance is dwarfed by the $7 trillion in environmentally harmful subsidies identified in the U.N. Environment Programme’s latest State of Finance for Nature report, , opens new tab which Global Canopy co-authored. That is 30 times more than the $200 billion in finance flows to nature-based solutions.State of Finance for Nature report, , opens new tabAccording to the report, finance flows to nature-based solutions must almost triple to reach $542 billion per year by 2030 and $737 billion by 2050 if the world is to achieve global climate and biodiversity goals.Global Canopy is hoping that a new tool will help unblock one of the biggest barriers that have prevented companies and investors to make progress on deforestation pledges: the confusing data landscape.In the runup to COP28, Global Canopy, the Stockholm Environment Institute and the Zoological Society of London (ZSL) launched Forest IQ , opens new tab , an open platform that promises to provide “actionable data” on how more than 2,000 major companies are addressing their links to deforestation.Forest IQ , opens new tabForest IQ aggregates more than 2,400 data points across seven datasets, including Global Canopy’s Forest 500 list, Trase, ZSL SPOTT, and the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO).An aerial view shows a deforested plot of the Amazon rainforest in Manaus, Amazonas State, Brazil. REUTERS/Bruno Kelly Purchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights , opens new tabThe platform has been developed in consultation with 10 financial institutions, including BlackRock and Axa, and tested by more than 50 other organisations.Eugenie Mathieu, nature stewardship lead for Aviva Investors, said at the launch of Forest IQ in November that Aviva had been among 35 financial institutions that signed up at COP26 in Glasgow to the financial sector deforestation commitment , opens new tab (known as FSDA) to eliminate commodity-driven deforestation from their portfolios by 2025, but has struggled to make headway.financial sector deforestation commitment , opens new tabShe said it had been surprisingly difficult to do a deforestation risk assessment. “It's very challenging, matching a portfolio of thousands of listed companies, some with complicated ownership structures. None of us are data scientists so we don’t know how to do it and I am really grateful that this tool will help us get there more quickly.”Mardas said the next step will be to launch a new initiative, called deforestation-free transition pathways, later this year, “which will help move companies along the journey in a predictable and scientifically sensible way,” while avoiding greenwash issues surrounding deforestation commitments.“We get around the confusion problem (for companies) because it's a much more ordered framework, and we get around the greenwash problem because we're saying that ‘if you're a stage three company, we expect you to do X and Y and Z and we can have indicators for X,Y and Z, so we can know within 12 months whether you actually did those things.”He added: “The idea is to then link in with transition pathways on climate and nature as a kind of currency and language that the market understands.”Investors and policymakers have to get a wiggle on, Mardas adds. The next two years will be critical, with COP30 due to be held in Belem, in the heart of the Amazon. President Lula da Silva wants to show the world he’s made headway on his promises to end deforestation and transform the economy into a nature-friendly economy.But he faces a battle to push through his agenda in a Congress that is still friendly to the former president Jair Bolsonaro, Mardas said. “A lot of our thinking and a lot of our work is now focused on how can the world’s biggest rainforest nation play a pivotal leading role (on ending deforestation) on a time-track to COP 30.”Opinions expressed are those of the author. They do not reflect the views of Reuters News, which, under the Trust Principles, is committed to integrity, independence, and freedom from bias. Ethical Corporation Magazine, a part of Reuters Professional, is owned by Thomson Reuters and operates independently of Reuters News.Purchase Licensing RightsTerry SlavinThomson ReutersTerry Slavin is editor-in-chief of Reuters Events Sustainable Business, and edits Ethical Corporation, Thomson Reuters' sustainable business magazine, based in London. She also commissions commentary and contributes to the Industry Insights column on the sustainability section of Reuters.com. Terry has specialised in business and environment issues throughout her career, both as a writer and editor. She has worked for news publications in her native Canada, Australia, for the Asian Wall Street Journal in Hong Kong, Knight-Ridder news agency in London and The Guardian, among others, before becoming editor of Ethical Corporation. She is particularly interested in the intersection between business, nature and development issues. @tslavinm

title: New bar exam developers ditch problem-plagued ExamSoft platform
author: By Karen Sloan
content: CompaniesExamsoft Worldwide, Inc.Examsoft Worldwide, Inc.FollowJan 31 (Reuters) - The revamped bar exam set to debut in July 2026 won’t rely on ExamSoft—the testing platform that has suffered a series of tech problems over the years.The National Conference of Bar Examiners said on Tuesday that it had replaced ExamSoft, the platform most states use for the current bar exam, with different testing software for the NextGen bar exam.The bar examiners' switch to Surpass Assessment software comes after a number of technology issues with ExamSoft. The company paid $2.1 million in 2015 to settle a lawsuit brought by bar exam takers who couldn’t upload their test answers—an incident that became known as “barmageddon” in legal publications.A spokesperson for ExamSoft parent company Turnitin on Wednesday said that it "continues to provide bar exam services" to states, and declined to comment further.ExamSoft's software also came under scrutiny during the COVID-19 pandemic, when many states administered the exam remotely using laptop microphones and cameras to monitor for cheating. Some July 2021 examinees across the country had their computers crash mid-test. An investigation by the State Bar of California found that nearly 31% of the people who took the state’s remote exam experienced tech issues, and 2% lost time or answers as a result. ExamSoft attributed the problems to the video proctoring portion of the software using more memory than anticipated.computers crashinvestigationAdvertisement · Scroll to continueCurrently, states may choose from ExamSoft, Extegrity or ILG Technologies to deliver the written portions of their bar exams. California, New York and Florida now use ExamSoft, while Texas, Illinois and New Jersey use ILG. ILG declined to comment.Extegrity chief operating officer Greg Sarab told Reuters on Wednesday that requiring all states to use a single software platform is risky."If you have all your eggs in one basket and then it doesn't work, nobody else is ready to step in," he said.Advertisement · Scroll to continueA spokesperson for the National Conference declined to say how much it is paying Surpass to administer the exam.Surpass Assessment’s testing software is currently used by a number of professional licensing boards, including the National Board of Medical Examiners and American Nurses Credentialing Center.In addition to using Surpass to administer the test, the NextGen Bar Exam will be delivered entirely on computer—eliminating the paper question booklets and Scantron sheets where examinees bubble in answers to multiple-choice questions.Advertisement · Scroll to continueThe NextGen bar exam is intended to be more skills-oriented and rely less on the memorization of law. The National Conference will offer both the current exam and the NextGen test from July 2026 through February 2028, after which only the new test will be available.intendedRead more:New bar exam shaves three hours off testing timeNew bar exam shaves three hours off testing timeCalif. bar exam probe details tech failures, computer crashesCalif. bar exam probe details tech failures, computer crashesAdvertisement · Scroll to continueReporting by Karen SloanOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing RightsKaren SloanThomson ReutersKaren Sloan reports on law firms, law schools, and the business of law. Reach her at karen.sloan@thomsonreuters.com

title: Rare patent argument attracts US government, suspended judge
author: By Blake Brittain
content: summaryCompaniesLaw FirmsFull Federal Circuit hears landmark arguments over GM fender patentSuspended 96-year-old Federal Circuit jurist attends as observerFeb 5 (Reuters) - The U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit on Monday heard a rare full-court argument in a dispute between General Motors (GM.N) , opens new tab and auto-parts maker LKQ (LKQ.O) , opens new tab that could upend design-patent law.(GM.N) , opens new tab(LKQ.O) , opens new tabTen of the court's judges grappled with whether to invalidate a GM patent covering a vehicle fender, questioning the current test for design-patent validity while struggling with how to change it."We don't want to replace one potentially bad test with a different potentially bad test," Chief U.S. Circuit Judge Kimberly Moore said during the argument.The U.S. government also participated in the argument, telling the judges that they should adopt a more "holistic" test for determining when a design patent is obvious and invalid.Circuit Judge Pauline Newman, who was suspended from the Federal Circuit bench in September amid an internal investigation into her fitness to serve, attended the argument as an observer.suspended from the Federal Circuit benchAdvertisement · Scroll to continue"I have some ideas, but no one wanted to hear them," the prominent 96-year-old patent jurist said to reporters after the hearing.Design patents protect novel visual characteristics of manufactured objects. LKQ asked a U.S. Patent Office tribunal in 2022 to cancel a GM design patent covering a front vehicle fender after their licensing agreement expired and GM threatened to sue for infringement.LKQ argued GM's patent was invalid as obvious, citing two earlier designs that it said created the same visual impression as GM's. The board ruled for GM, and a three-judge panel of judges at the Federal Circuit, which hears all patent appeals, affirmed the decision last year.Advertisement · Scroll to continueThe full Federal Circuit agreed last June to rehear the case, marking its first full-court rehearing in a patent case since 2018. It said it would reconsider LKQ's argument that the obviousness test for design patents was overruled by a 2007 Supreme Court decision that rejected "rigid and mandatory formulas" for obviousness in the context of patents covering inventions.agreed last JuneAuto-parts companies told the appeals court that carmakers misuse design patents to stifle competition for aftermarket parts, and that affirming the decision would make replacement parts more expensive and harder to obtain.Advertisement · Scroll to continueCircuit Judge Jimmie Reyna asked why there had not been a larger "outcry" from designers about the case, and said it may be a "slippery slope" to create a new test without better knowing its ramifications.The case is LKQ Corp v. GM Global Technology Operations LLC, U.S. Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, No. 21-2348.For LKQ: Mark Lemley of Lex LuminaFor GM: Joseph Herriges of Fish & RichardsonAdvertisement · Scroll to continueFor the U.S. government: Farheena Rasheed of the U.S. Patent and Trademark OfficeJumpstart your morning with top legal news delivered straight to your inbox from The Daily Docket , opens new tab .The Daily Docket , opens new tabRead more:GM fender design victory in limbo after US appeals court grants rare reviewGM fender design victory in limbo after US appeals court grants rare reviewUS appeals judge, 96, suspended in rare clash over fitnessUS appeals judge, 96, suspended in rare clash over fitnessSuspended US appeals judge warns her treatment could erode confidence in judiciarySuspended US appeals judge warns her treatment could erode confidence in judiciaryReporting by Blake Brittain in WashingtonOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing RightsBlake BrittainThomson ReutersBlake Brittain reports on intellectual property law, including patents, trademarks, copyrights and trade secrets, for Reuters Legal. He has previously written for Bloomberg Law and Thomson Reuters Practical Law and practiced as an attorney.

title: Britain invests 100 million pounds in AI research and regulation
author: Reuters
content: LONDON, Feb 6 (Reuters) - Britain on Tuesday said it would spend more than 100 million pounds ($125 million) to launch nine new research hubs in artificial intelligence (AI) and train regulators about the technology."AI is moving fast, but we have shown that humans can move just as fast," technology minister Michelle Donelan said in a statement. "By taking an agile, sector-specific approach, we have begun to grip the risks immediately."Nearly 90 million pounds would go towards the hubs, which will focus on using AI in areas including healthcare, chemistry and mathematics, and a partnership with the United States on responsible AI, the government said.Another 10 million pounds would help regulators address the risks and harness the opportunities of AI, it said, such as developing practical tools to monitor risks in sectors from telecoms and healthcare to finance and education.Advertisement · Scroll to continueBritain hosted an international summit in November on AI safety.NovemberMore than 25 countries who attended signed the "Bletchley Declaration", , opens new tab which focuses on identifying risks of shared concern and developing cross-country policies to mitigate them."Bletchley Declaration", , opens new tab($1 = 0.7987 pounds)Reporting by Farouq Suleiman, Editing by Paul SandleOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: SK Innovation projects slower growth in global EV demand
author: By Heekyong Yang and Joyce Lee
content: summaryCompaniesMore than 80% of 2024 capex of about $6.8 bln to go batteriesCo expects battery unit to reach break-even point in H2 2024Economic stimulus measures, firmer travel demand to push up refining margins in 2024SEOUL, Feb 6 (Reuters) - South Korean energy group SK Innovation (096770.KS) , opens new tab , on Tuesday forecast slowing growth in global electric vehicle (EV) demand, joining an increasing number of automakers and suppliers expressing concern about the market for EVs.(096770.KS) , opens new tabThe owner of South Korea's biggest refiner SK Energy posted operating profit of 73 billion won ($54.75 million) for the fourth quarter ended December, compared with a 765 billion won loss a year earlier.The result was far below an average analyst forecast of 558 billion won profit compiled by LSEG SmartEstimate. The company said its petrochemical business swung to a loss due to weaker refining margins and lower prices.Fourth-quarter revenue rose 2.1% to 19.5 trillion won from the same period from year earlier.SK Innovation said it had a capital spending budget of about 9 trillion won for this year, slightly down from about 10 trillion won last year, with more than 80% allocated for its battery business as it continues to ramp up production abroad.Advertisement · Scroll to continueWhile battery unit SK On narrowed its operating loss to 18.6 billion won in the fourth quarter from 86.1 billion won in the previous quarter, it missed its previously announced target to turn a profit in the fourth quarter, adding that it aims to reach a break-even point in the second half of this year.missed its previously announced target"The overall battery shipment in the first half of this year would likely drop slightly, however, with automaker customers' launch of new EVs and lower interest rates supporting an increase battery shipments in the second half of the year," SK On Chief Financial Officer Kim Kyunghoon said in a post-earnings conference call.Advertisement · Scroll to continueSK On's major customer Ford Motor Co (F.N) , opens new tab last month said t would reduce production of its F-150 Lightning pickup truck as demand for EVs had been lower than expected.(F.N) , opens new tabreduce production of its F-150 Lightning pickup truckIn late January, SK On's cross-town rival LG Energy Solution (373220.KS) , opens new tab forecast slowing growth in the EV market this year, signalling further challenges ahead amid intensifying competition from Chinese rivals.(373220.KS) , opens new tabslowing growth in the EV marketSK, which has total refining capacity of 1.115 million barrels per day at its plants in Ulsan and Incheon, said it expects economic stimulus measures and firmer travel demand backed by the lunar New Year holiday in China to push up refining margins.Advertisement · Scroll to continueThe oil major also said it will shut its 40,000 barrels per day (bpd) No. 1 and No. 2 vacuum residue desulphurisation (VRDS) units at the Ulsan refinery for maintenance in the first quarter of 2024.The company, however, did not specify an exact time frame. A VRDS unit typically breaks down residue oil from the refinery's vacuum distillation unit into products such as low-sulphur fuel oil.The time line is likely to be sometime from mid-March to mid-April for the first unit and end-March to early May for the second unit, said three trading sources.Advertisement · Scroll to continueShares in SK Innovation were down 4.6% in morning trade, versus the benchmark KOSPI's (.KS11) , opens new tab 0.6% fall.(.KS11) , opens new tab($1 = 1,331.8000 won)Reporting by Heekyong Yang and Joyce Lee; Additional reporting by Trixie Yap; Editing by Sonali Paul and Christopher CushingOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: Stellantis exploring sale of anonymised data packages to service providers
author: Reuters
content: CompaniesStellantis NVStellantis NVFollowFeb 6 (Reuters) - Stellantis is in discussions with customers about offering anonymised data packages from its vehicles to service providers, an executive said on Tuesday, confirming an earlier report in German media outlet WELT.The carmaker is currently in talks with customers over securing their consent, said Sanjiv Ghate, head of the responsible business unit at Stellantis, Mobilisights.The types of data that could be sold include information on how an electric car's battery status changes dependent on road or weather conditions, which could help city planners identify where charging points are needed, according to Ghate.Other use cases included linking traffic data to economic data to understand movement around individual neighbourhoods or assessing road conditions to determine where there is a need for repairs.The company would also be open to making data available to researchers or government agencies with the appropriate licensing, he said, adding he was open to collaborations with other data providers.Reporting by Victoria Waldersee, Editing by Miranda MurrayOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: UK House of Lords report urges EV subsidies, faster charger rollout
author: By Nick Carey and Sachin Ravikumar
content: LONDON, Feb 6 (Reuters) - The UK government should take urgent action to encourage people to switch to electric vehicles, from targeted subsidies to speeding up new charging infrastructure, said a report from Britain's upper house of parliament released on Tuesday.The House of Lords report, entitled "EV strategy: rapid recharge needed," which follows an inquiry into Britain's electric vehicle transition strategy, also calls on the government to clearly communicate to the general public why they should buy EVs.inquiry"They have got to do what politicians don't like to do, which is get into the space of talking to people about how they live their lives and how they're going to support them to do it," Baroness Kathryn Parminter, who chaired the inquiry, said in an interview. "That is the gaping hole and that is where the government's got to put its foot on the gas."The Lords report calls for targeted incentives to make EVs more accessible for lower-income car owners. It also says the government should "turbo-charge" the building of new charging infrastructure, including by reviewing "outdated and disproportionate planning regulations which are a major block to the rollout."Advertisement · Scroll to continueA lack of charging infrastructure has been a significant obstacle to broader mass adoption of electric cars.The report comes as Britain sold its one-millionth fully-electric vehicle in January. But while overall EV sales have risen, industry group the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) warned that falling demand from private buyers meant the UK government should take action to subsidize sales.take actionAdvertisement · Scroll to continueA spokesperson for the UK transport ministry said a decade of government grants and incentives had led to more than 1 million EVs on British roads."The government is targeting its investment where it will have the most impact, to ensure value for money for the taxpayer," the spokesperson said.Last September, British Prime Minister Rishi Sunak announced a delay to the country's ban on fossil-fuel cars to 2035 from 2030, citing the "unacceptable costs" to British households.country's banReporting by Nick Carey and Sachin Ravikumar, Editing by Rosalba O'BrienOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing RightsSachin RavikumarThomson ReutersSachin Ravikumar is a correspondent for Reuters in London covering general news from across the UK. Over nine years at Reuters, he has helped run various breaking news teams, reported on business and general news from India and worked as a desk editor.

title: VinFast recalls nearly 6,000 units in Vietnam to replace switch
author: Reuters
content: CompaniesVinFast Auto LtdVinFast Auto LtdFollowHANOI, Feb 6 (Reuters) - Vietnam's electric vehicle (EV) maker VinFast is recalling nearly 6,000 of its VF 5 cars sold in the domestic market to replace the combination switch, the company said on Tuesday.The vehicles being recalled were manufactured from March to December last year, it said in a statement, adding only one vehicle sold on the market was recorded with the switch error and no incidents have occurred.VinFast discovered during tests that the front lights on some VF 5 Plus vehicles, which are available only in Vietnam, are turned off if the driver pulls the combination switch strongly to turn on the ignition, the EV maker said.The problem was with a control circuit board design error from the component supplier, it added.VinFast, which made its Nasdaq debut last August delivered nearly 35,000 cars in 2023, below its target of at least 40,000 units.The deliveries in the last three months of 2023, however, increased 35% against the third quarter to 13,513 units, the company has said.Reporting by Phuong Nguyen; Editing by Martin PettyOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: Record sales in Indian financial stocks snap FPI buying streak in January
author: By Bharath Rajeswaran
content: BENGALURU, Feb 6 (Reuters) - Foreign portfolio investors (FPI) sold a record amount of Indian financials in January - the sector in which they have the largest holdings - after the country's largest lender HDFC Bank posted disappointing earnings, according to National Securities Depository data , opens new tab .data , opens new tabThe monthly selling in financials, worth about 300 billion rupees, snapped the FPI buying streak in Indian equities.FPIs sold stocks worth 257.44 billion rupees ($3.10 billion) in January after a record monthly buying in December.record"We see FPI outflows in January as a temporary blip. They will likely turn net buyers in the next few months," said Neeraj Dewan, director at Quantum Securities."The January FPI sale is predominantly due to the disappointment from the HDFC Bank results, which hurt sentiment," added Dewan.resultsReuters GraphicsFPI selling triggered a 4.61% fall in financials (.NIFTYFIN) , opens new tab and a 0.03% drop in the Nifty 50 index in January.(.NIFTYFIN) , opens new tabAdvertisement · Scroll to continueReuters GraphicsFPIs had turned net buyers in November and the monthly purchases hit a record in December on hopes of early rate cuts in the United States.With gains of 5.52% in November and a subsequent climb of 7.94% in December, the Nifty 50 concluded 2023 with the best monthly gains since July 2022.Reuters Graphics"While the onset of U.S. rate cuts could be delayed, resilience in the U.S. labour market and cooling inflation have strengthened the narrative that there shall be a soft landing," said Mayuresh Joshi, head of equity research - India at William O'Neil and Company.Advertisement · Scroll to continueIf the demand recovery plays out as expected, FPI inflows in the information technology sector should rise further over the next two quarters, Joshi added.IT stocks witnessed FPI buying to the tune of 44.85 billion rupees, the most among major sectors, in January.Despite posting lacklustre results, the IT index (.NIFTYIT) , opens new tab gained 3.16% during the month, driven by liquidity.(.NIFTYIT) , opens new tab($1 = 83.0550 Indian rupees)Reporting by Bharath Rajeswaran in Bengaluru; Editing by Sohini GoswamiOur Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabThe Thomson Reuters Trust Principles. , opens new tabPurchase Licensing Rights

title: Alphabet is seeking outside investment for its GFiber internet business
author: By Jeffrey Dastin
